title: Before 14 August 2021, will an executive order be signed or federal legislation become law that would forgive $10,000 or more in principal on federal student loan debts for at least five million student loan borrowers?
preds:
Biden Administration Starts Overhaul Of Student Loan Forgiveness, Income Based Repayment Programs - Forbes
https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamminsky/2021/08/09/biden-administration-starts-overhaul-of-student-loan-forgiveness-income-based-repayment-programs/
Mon, 09 Aug 2021 15:30:04 GMT

5 Key Takeaways From Biden’s Extension Of Student Loan Relief - Forbes
https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamminsky/2021/08/07/5-key-takeaways-from-bidens-extension-of-student-loan-relief/
Sat, 07 Aug 2021 13:43:11 GMT This Hidden Clue Suggests Biden Won’t Extend Student Loan Relief - Forbes
https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/08/02/this-hidden-clue-suggests-biden-wont-extend-student-loan-relief/
Mon, 02 Aug 2021 14:38:18 GMT Forbes: Not a superforecaster.

Moratorium extended to January, no chance of loan forgiveness this week. It's nice to be right once in awhile. My first forecast on this issue, 17 Mar: "Biden has frozen student loan payments through October 2021 already. I expect he will not take action before this deadline. I further expect if he does take action, it will be another exec order to delay payments further, to give congress more time to legislate this issue. I expect Congress to fail to do so..." Though in contrast to March, I'm less convinced Congress will act on this issue OR the admin will forgive loans before the now-extended moratorium runs out.
It was a  Democratic campaign promise.. so it will never happen.

Pelosi: President Biden Does Not Have Power To Cancel Student Loan Debt — What It Means For Borrowers - Forbes
https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamminsky/2021/07/28/pelosi-president-biden-does-not-have-power-to-cancel-student-loan-debt/
Wed, 28 Jul 2021 17:23:30 GMT > In explosive comments today, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) told reporters that President Biden does not have authority to cancel student loan debt.
> “People think that the President of the United States has the power for debt forgiveness,” she said. “He does not. He can postpone, he can delay, but he does not have that power.” Pelosi argued that student loan forgiveness can only be accomplished through “an act of Congress.”
> Pelosi’s comments are sure to cause controversy, as other leading Democrats in Congress continue to push for broad cancellation of student loan debt. Yesterday, Pelosi’s counterpart in the Senate, Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY), held a press conference along with Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) and Rep. Ayanna Pressley (D-MA), urging President Biden to cancel $50,000 or more in student loan debt. “President Biden should use his existing legal authority to cancel up to $50,000 in student debt,” Schumer said in remarks, contradicting Pelosi’s subsequent comments. Schumer donned a “cancel student debt” face mask during his press conference.
> In her remarks today, Pelosi also questioned whether student loan cancellation was even prudent, arguing that taxpayers may not necessarily want their tax dollars utilized to cancel someone else’s debt, suggesting that she may not even support mass student loan forgiveness in a Congressional bill, should Biden not act using his executive authority.  *** It could be confirmation bias on my part (after all, Shumer is arguing the opposite), but this halves my probability from 4 to 2%.

Biden Has Now Cancelled $40 Billion Of Student Loans This Way - Forbes
https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/07/14/biden-cancelled-40-billion-of-student-loans-this-way/
Wed, 14 Jul 2021 16:30:58 GMT Here Are the Possible Winners and Losers in a Student Loan Proposal - The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/16/upshot/student-loans-biden.html
Fri, 16 Jul 2021 09:00:17 GMT Student Loans Are Due Starting October 1, But Make Sure You Know The Answers To These 10 Questions - Forbes
https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/07/12/student-loans-may-be-due-starting-october-1---here-are-answers-to-10-popular-questions/
Mon, 12 Jul 2021 23:08:58 GMT
This is more likely closer to the midterms. Voters have short memories.

+3 "The Department of Education has canceled a total of $1.5 billion in student loan debt for nearly 92,000 students, who were victims of for-profit college fraud, since President Joe Biden took office." It's a start. https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/09/politics/biden-student-loan-debt-cancellation/index.html

Times running out on this one.  Not going to happen, because people that understand the issue realize that this disproportionally benefits upper income households (i.e. doctors and attorneys).  Not a very progressive policy at the end of the day.

Biden campaigned on cancelling and reforming student debt. Here's where those promises stand. - Business Insider
https://www.businessinsider.com/student-loan-debt-forgiveness-biden-campaign-promises-education-department-2021-6
Sun, 27 Jun 2021 12:35:19 GMT
Not enough to affect question resolution: https://greekreporter.com/2021/06/18/joe-biden-cancels-3-billion-worth-of-student-debt/
staying at 5% for a while longer

Biden offering debt forgiveness on $10,000 for 5,000,000 followers defrauded by for profit colleges shows political will to accomplish this, but likely pushes it back in the agenda before August 14th.
Pressure seems low given the freeze through September plus other more pressing legislative items. https://www.nerdwallet.com/article/loans/student-loans/joe-biden-student-loans
I wasn't watching this one. With deadline extended until September. It doesn't seem this is going to happen in the timeframe.

No inclusion of student debt in latest budget, and seems unlikely he will sign executive order when he is getting a lot done through legislative process: https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.businessinsider.com/bidens-budget-campaign-promises-student-debt-and-healthcare-reform-2021-5%3famp

Reducing significantly because of doubts about whether the Education Department will finish their report, and frankly I just don't think student debt is a huge priority for Biden right now. Even if he does end up doing it, he may very well compromise and cancel less than 10,000. Source: https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/white-house-promised-memo-biden-s-authority-cancel-student-debt-n1268681

Biden Budget Omits Broad Student Loan Forgiveness—Here’s Where Things Stand In Washington On Relief - Forbes
https://www.forbes.com/sites/sarahhansen/2021/05/28/biden-budget-omits-broad-student-loan-forgiveness-heres-where-things-stand-in-washington-on-relief/
Fri, 28 May 2021 20:50:43 GMT
Passage of time. Hah, that was fun to say. Note to self: stop being so noisy.
-5 based on the article provided by @LokiOdinevich
ticking down from 10% to 9% based on the passage of time and the article provided by @LokiOdinevich

Biden Drops Student Loan Forgiveness From Latest Budget - Forbes
https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/05/21/biden-drops-student-loan-forgiveness-from-latest-budget/
Sat, 22 May 2021 03:04:31 GMT Going down slightly

Going to zero and throwing in the towel on my highly contrary view against the crowd that this would happen before August 2021.  The WaPo reports that next week's budget leaves out any mention of student debt cancellation.[1]  My mistaken view was so strong based on my belief that Biden and his senior advisors had learned from Obama's failures of incrementalism.  I think that view holds but the politics are just not in their favor with the 50/50 Senate and the intransigence from Manchin and Synema to stop minority-rule in the Senate.  I did not give enough weight to their clearly enunciated views.  When I did consider them, I engaged in hand waving to believe those two could be persuaded "some how." The absence of a health care public option and, more broadly, the lack of attention to health care in the budget, along with the exclusion of debt cancellation are harbingers of a tough 2022 mid-term election for the Dems, in my view.  All of this, plus the unlikelihood of passing the For The People Act, which overturns the most anti-democratic Red State laws, is a cascade from Joe Manchin's decision to oppose filibuster reform.  We are likely to see Speaker Kevin McCarthy thwart Biden's agenda for the final two years of his first term. Perhaps Biden is keeping this in his back pocket for executive action in September or October before the 2022 mid-term election in November if Congress does not take action, which is his clearly preferred choice.  Nonetheless, that will be outside the terms of reference for a "yes" on this question.  [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2021/05/21/white-house-biden-health/
Dropping on time but less than straight line as the rhetoric is still continuing.
They will  have to come back with a better plan , as it stands right now, it is no passing any vote.

Just not happening.   What most people do not understand, despite the aggressive push from progressives, is that this proposal disproportionality benefits the upper class, to a lesser degree, but not insignificantly, the middle class and barley the lower class.  There is really no incentive for the Biden Administration, based on their stated policy objectives, an EO would be inconsistent.

Democrats Propose To Forgive Student Loans With 4 Changes - Forbes
https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/05/09/democrats-urge-immediate-student-loan-relief-and-propose-4-ways-to-fix-student-loan-forgiveness/
Sun, 09 May 2021 13:02:49 GMT Note that this is for people who have worked for the government for 10+ years.

The Biden Administration doesn't want to rush into this. They have to make sure the DOE's legal memo on whether there is executive branch authority to cancel the loans is ironclad: https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/04/03/biden-student-loans-review-could-mean-this-for-student-loan-cancellation/?sh=6f1a36d08cbd
Next, there's still lots of time. Student loans are all in deferment until October: https://www.nerdwallet.com/article/loans/student-loans/student-loan-covid-forbearance
Updating upwards on account of discussion
Only way this is going to happen is by Executive Order and it is unclear if it can be done via an Executive Order.
This might be something to consider when midterms are getting close in order to spur student, young people, and recently educated, participation in the election, groups that are leaning democrat.

Biden has unveiled his next big round of proposals. Now is the time when we would hope to see it and it hasn't materialized. Particularly given the amount of money Biden is considering spending I don't think this policy proposal makes the cut. We will see which laws get passed. If enough of them get blocked, I suspect Biden might do something unilaterally.
Whoops, forgot to actually adjust the forecast.
The Biden administration has asked DOE if they have authority to do this. So they are certainly thinking about it.

Raising on the news that Biden is considering cancelling up to 50,000 by executive order (https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamminsky/2021/04/01/biden-actively-considering-cancelling-student-loan-debt-of-up-to-50000/?sh=22044ae938e8).

Small bump in numbers dues to the confirmation that amendments to budget reconciliation measures are not party to the filibuster rule.  I still don't think they would attempt to push this though as part of the infrastructure bill, but the opportunity to pass legislation without needed to deal with the filibuster is a big deal. https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/EXPLAINER-Senate-eyes-budget-rule-to-push-past-16081541.php
I am selfishly hoping this happens and based this number on a couple comments.

+6 on Klain’s comments today.[1].  My reading of Klain’s framing is that Biden will act when he has the views of Department of Education and Justice.  This DOE is clearly disposed to cancel debt, having already cleared $1 billion for defrauded students at for-profit schools.  The question is whether the DoJ’s Office of Legal Counsel is more likely than not to side with those who believe the executive branch has authority on its own to cancel student debt apart from the legislature.  Executive branch lawyers tend to reflexively assert executive power.  The acting head of OLC Christopher Schroeder was brought back in after serving in the OLC under Obama and Clinton.  He was also a staffer for Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee.  This suggests he can be relied upon to be friendly to the mainstream of respectable Democratic views on the law.  I am guessing he will agree with all of those smart Harvard lawyers who say the president can cancel student debt on his own. [1] https://www.axios.com/biden-student-debt-50k-10k-cancel-forgive-klain-e41886f7-fc1a-42d6-b2bc-ce4cc1c3ac2b.html

+2 https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/biden-review-executive-authority-cancel-student-debt-n1262791 "In an interview with Politico, Klain said Biden will make a decision on how to proceed once he reviews the memo, which could be sent to his desk within the next few weeks." I thought +5 but decided to temper that a bit because of this: https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/03/29/heres-the-latest-on-student-loan-cancellation/?sh=d6956a926617

"1. Don’t expect student loan cancellation anytime soon"
https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/03/29/heres-the-latest-on-student-loan-cancellation/

Change: -10 Reasoning: This was not included in the initial discussions of the 3 trillion build back better law. Which is not a good sign. Free community college was included and I am wondering if that will take most of the thunder.
-10 on passage of time, the growing possibility it doesn't happen before August, and following the crowd a bit.

https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-3-trillion-infrastructure-fbf6fcb8ca51ab5b4b45b5318046e831 Likely to be included in this bill, with a target price of $3T. It would cost $429 bn (14% of the package.)
No change in forecast, but with immigration an increasingly pressing issue right now, I don't think Biden will try to use valuable political capital on student loan forgiveness this year.
Increasing divisiveness in Congress. This issue is unlikely to be the one that Democrats fall on their sword for

With the recent $1.9T congressional relief bill (a whopping 10% of GDP) signed into law, I cannot see how Congress could pass another large scale wealth transfer bill that would add to the federal debt. Dropping forecast from 10% to 5%

Exec order: will DOJ find it within the president's existing authority? will they rule early enough for Biden to act before 14 Aug? Will he do so if they rule affirmatively? Legislation: will the parliamentarian rule a student loan forgiveness plan can make it through reconciliation? will the democrats put it in their second and final reconciliation bill of the year? does loan forgiveness have the support of all 50 democratic senators? if it can't be passed through reconciliation, can the senate bring it to the floor for a vote? can they do so by 14 Aug? Biden has frozen student loan payments through October 2021 already (https://www.cnbc.com/select/biden-extending-federal-student-loans-freeze/). I expect he will not take action before this deadline. I further expect if he does take action, it will be another exec order to delay payments further, to give congress more time to legislate this issue. I expect Congress to fail to do so, and for Biden to use the authority the DOJ affirms he has, but not before the deadline imposed in this question.
Change:+5 Reasoning: there was a provision in the stimulus to make forgiveness tax-free. Sounds like they are planning on at least trying to forgive this year.

I am going to increase on the information that Congress did not include it in the COVID relief package, which may incentivize the Executive Branch to take it upon themselves. Timing and legality is still in question so this I think is reflected in my probability forecast for this update. Maybe student loan relief was not included so it would not be a topic of debate in a bill that was much desired among many Americans.
Recent press reports suggest upcoming stimulus bill sets path for student debt cancellation.

I'm gonna reduce due to the delay in seeing if the executive order is lawful. I think if it is seen as a lawful option for Biden, it shouldn't take this long to approve. The fact that they even had to probe its lawfulness is doubt to him actually being able to sign an EO. If I were to give it a 100% chance of success in 4 years, passing it within this question window gives you an 11% hit probability. I am going to trust that not everything Biden aspires to do will be done within the first year. I think the priority for education will be getting back to school safely. When campuses open back up, enrollment may increase, which means maybe more loans??? Could this pressure Congress further?

New news, bad optics for me:
"Another factor that may impact the timing and likelihood of student debt forgiveness being enacted is how smoothly new Department of Education officials are transitioned into power. On Friday, federal student aid chief Mark Brown resigned. Brown, a retired major general in the U.S. Air Force who was appointed by former Education Secretary Betsy DeVos in March 2019, shared the announcement in a video message sent to his staff saying, 'As I step aside I appeal to you to do whatever is necessary to support the policy elements of the current administration.' "
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/05/senate-covid-relief-bill-would-make-student-debt-forgiveness-tax-free.html https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/18/how-165-billion-default-student-debt-impacts-forgiveness-calculations.html

This is unlikely before August, I think the other side of the aisle only has the stomach for one major fiscal policy / handout in a year.  If Biden genuinely wants to be a reconciliation President, he won't trigger Republican sensitivities so soon after forcing the Covid relief bill through this month.  And if he can't pass the Covid relief package into law, forgiving student debt becomes an issue to be resolved later anyway.
This tweet seems to indicate that it's highly unlikely to happen through executive action by the expiration date: https://twitter.com/PressSec/status/1357398773782237186

-2 from my previous forecast because the Senate Parliamentarian recently ruled that reconciliation could not be used for minimum wage increase and is likely to rule the same way on student loan debt relief.

-10. Still think this is more likely than not before the next Senate election, just not sure it can get done in the question timeframe. It's not attached to the new COVID relief currently so to me that lowers the likelihood of it happening in the timeframe.

Biden is unlikely to use EO for student loan relief. He has supported $10,000 in aid but he has too many other priorities (COVID, Foreign Affairs, etc.) to justify student loan relief. (https://www.nerdwallet.com/article/loans/student-loans/joe-biden-student-loans.) +5 because someone mentioned reconciliation. I hadn't considered that he might get it added to a bill.

Conversations around $15 federal minimum wage have evaporated. With stimulus talks already on the table for 2021 I do not see student loan forgiveness becoming a political topic for 2021 while schools are not in proper session, and the public is becoming worried about federal spending in the wake of COVID relief driving asset prices up.

Change: +22. Reasoning: I think I have been too influenced by the crowd average. In reality, I think there is way too much ambiguity to be in the 70-30 range. To review what we know:
- One of Biden's campaign proposals was to abolish $10,000 of student debt.
- Biden has expressed a desire to do via legislation. 
-There is belief that he could do it via executive order. Biden does not he believe he has that authority but that is immaterial. A bunch of lefties do (Warren, Schumer, etc.), citing alleged authority under the higher education act of 1965. Legal experts (https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertfarrington/2020/12/17/can-biden-really-forgive-student-loans-by-executive-order/?sh=ad425281eed5) think it is ambiguous and likely to be challenged if the executive order is implemented.
- Biden will ask Merrick Garland to review the law in coordination with his policy committee once Garland is appointed. They will come to a judgement. Then they will debate the policy.
- If it does not become passed via executive order, it may be passed via Budget Reconciliation. The dems have one more shot at Budget reconciliation after the current bill. TLDR: There are two ways this question could resolve in the affirmative. I don't think either is really likely but they each have a chance. Biden is putting the executive order through a process, so I suspect we will get an honest legal judgment. Then they will debate the merits of doing an executive order and I am pretty sure they will determine that it will be challenged in court and risky. I give this a 10% chance.  The Budget Reconciliation bill is feasible but depends on the support of Joe Manchin, but we don't know where he stands. I think the biggest obstacle here is that the next BR bill is allegedly going to be focused on Infrastructure spending. I don't know if they are going to add a loan provision, but baseline Biden has said he wants to.
+10% for DOJ review of executive action for Biden (https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/02/17/biden-will-ask-doj-to-review-student-loans/?sh=7e9805933605)

Crowd's too confident in a no on this one. There's going to be a stimulus bill and DoJ is reviewing his ability to do an executive order. He's signalled he's willing to do $10,000 when progressive ask is $50,000. I'm going to go contrarian and say more likely than not.
Agree with @Jibreel_PCV, Biden considered executive action but he would have done it by now if he will at all. -5%

Based on Biden's comments at the town hall on Tuesday and Jen Psaki's follow-up comments, I continue to believe $10,000 for at least five million borrowers is highly likely in some form before August 14.  The second CARES Act is on track to pass via reconciliation in mid-March, according to news media, allowing a vehicle to attach this provision.[1]  Reconciliation bills cannot be filibustered. From CNN: Biden argues that the government shouldn't forgive debt for people who went to "Harvard and Yale and Penn" -- and he's also indicated that he believes Congress should make changes through legislation, which would make them harder to undo.  "The President has and continues to support canceling $10,000 of federal student loan debt per person as a response to the Covid crisis," White House press secretary Jen Psaki said at a briefing in February after the lawmakers introduced the resolution."[2] [1] https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-democrats-efforts-approve-biden-rescue-plan-within-month-march-2021-2
[2] https://edition.cnn.com/2021/02/16/politics/student-loan-forgiveness-biden/index.html

Change (-10): Biden last night signaled that the executive order is pretty much off the table. I think we'll see if this makes its way into the next reconciliation bill, but I'm becoming less and less hopeful.

Back up to 25% on Biden saying that is his limit. He could sign an EO that would do that.  I think even that would be challenged in court ujt he seems comfortable doing it.  Alternate is he goes with income repayment plans.  It is my observation that he is a product of the legislative branch and truly belkeves it is Congress responsibility to budget and spend.

Biden says he's "prepared" to do it by executive order for $10k. This seems fairly likely to happen one way or another, the big question in my mind is whether it happens by August. https://amp.usatoday.com/amp/6778938002?__twitter_impression=true
Schumer and Warren say it has to be 50k. Biden says no. Probably a compromise will be found that will include a sum higher than 10k.

Change (-5). Reasoning: I'm starting to wonder if Schumer is calling on Biden to do this because he knows Manchin is going to vote against it. That would lower the probability of doing it through another budget reconciliation bill.
After blocking impeachment the Democrats will go for an easy win.  This will be a bipartisan bill so will be an uphill battle.

Lowering to 10.
1)path via legislation blocked by filibuster.
2) path via reconciliation is viable.
3) path be executive order to directly (in the order) state amount to forgive is very slim. To much responsibility for Prez to take directly for such a complicated topic and he has indicated an aversion to debt forgiveness directly.
4) path via EO directing Dept of Ed to start a rulemaking to determine the threshold income limits and debt forgiveness tiers and implement process is most likely but would take 6 months to wonk (yes, wonk) out. This resolution would miss the question timeline and if it did occur prior to aug 14 it would not explicitly satisfy the question because the actual EO would not have forgiven the debt nor the thresholds (only directing DOE to issue regulaions to forgive the debt).

Lowering confidence due to the reluctance to budge upward by very thoughtful people on here. There still seems to be uncertainty whether Biden would actually commit to EO and whether the numbers are enough to trigger a YES. Additionally, the outside view of bills passing in Congress in general is something like 4%. I may regret going up so suddenly, then dropping back down.

The one part of the bill that has been publicly released so far does not have anything in it on this debt forgiveness: https://oversight.house.gov/sites/democrats.oversight.house.gov/files/Committee%20on%20Oversight%20and%20Reform%20Coronavirus%20Relief%20Measures%20Legislation.pdf
This indicates it's a bit lower priority, at least for now. Therefore lowering my odds

M feeling is Joe would prefer to use Executive orders ONLY when necessary.  The Legislative avenue may NOT be a slam dunk if it could be filibustered, so the lower barred RECONCILIATION* approach seems the best "politics" for all.  Further, the "numbers" required to be hit (for this to be a YES)  aren't "a complete Debt Jubilee" (to paraphrase @Francis_Urquhart) and could also therefore be "pragmatic" in the eyes of Centrist Repubs... That then leaves timing window to beat. *I don't know the micro-process of Reconcilliation well. Is there a "likely" reconciliation "bill" to fit this into? If a good story can be written through that route, it would seem to be doable, before time... and I'll be "smelling the barn door":-)   Any experts on that?  Upping my bet to 50, above the current crowd for now
tucking in with the crowd for a bit...
Increasing by 5% due to Biden considering executive action

I am with @Francis_Urquhart's high-confidence update. In addition, I had read the question wrong all along. I gave low estimates because I thought only Executive Order would count as YES when, in fact, a federal legislation from Congress would suffice. With Biden's willingness to consider Executive Order, my confidence rebounds upward. Now the question is whether Congress will propose a law; if yes, Biden still signs. The only way this goes NO is if both forget about this because of low priority. However, they have been talking about this for several months. Therefore, I do think they consider this high priority. And with the pandemic and looming fall semester around the question deadline, I see incentive for Congress to tackle this problem - there is already support from leadership in the majority. I leave room for the chance this is left by the wayside / becomes no longer relevant, or one of the resolution factors is not met. However, cumulatively I see this chance as low.

Raising my estimate due to comments by White House spox Jen Psaki saying the President is considering executive action on up to $50,000 in debt cancellation.(1)  Even compromising on $10,000 now fulfills Biden’s campaign promise and makes him appear to be governing for the middle.   (1) https://www.washingtonpost.com/education/2021/02/04/biden-democrats-student-debt-forgiveness/

Change (-4). Two bits of news:
1) Dems look likey to use Budget reconciliation for the covid stimulus bill. Reconciliation can only be used once per year so it seems less likely this will be done through legislative action.
2) Progressive senators and Chuck Schumer called on Biden again to cancel the debt with an executive order today. This suggests to me that they also don't think it will happen legislatively and that they are not letting the issue die. I think this is somewhere between 40-55. I am leaning conservative because this forum is, because it is wise to bet against something happening, and because I know Biden would hate to spend 650 Billion on an executive order. But it is not improbable.
Decreasing because negotiations on the second COVID stimulus bill will probably take some time

Moving to more or less in line with consensus. Can rationalise as not in this stimulus bill, potentially there is a 2/3rds or lower chance of another stimulus bill and perhaps a 1/3 chance it makes it into the new one if not in this one. That gets you to just over 20% as a cap, probably should be a bit lower, but then there is a residual chance it gets done through some other means.

Lowering based on historical NO (crowd and myself) and the conjunction fallacy. If Biden submits a budget to Congress, it could or could not include anything related to student loans. I think Biden is inclined to delegate this to Congress. If he does not submit anything pertaining to student loans, it may not be a priority (maybe they spend too much and are being conservative with funds) or he will indeed sign an EO on his own hands.

Going now way BELOW the crowd. 6.5 mos to the close. Biden won't be independently "activist" on this. He's "paused" but that's not "forgiveness". "Federal legislation becoming Law" is not his worry. Congress/Senate effecting signed legislation (of such broad specificity) is unlikely too.

Federal student loan payment are currently paused until September and President Biden has stated that he wants Congress to pass legislation on this topic. These two factors decrease the chance that an executive order will be signed to forgive federal student loan debts. Congress will likely pass legislation on this topic but I think it will happen after the 14 August deadline. If a bill is introduced in the House of Representatives or Senate I will adjust this forecast.

"Members of the subreddit are often young retail traders and investors who ignore fundamental investment practices and risk management techniques, so their activity is considered gambling. The growing popularity of no-commission brokers and mobile online trading has potentially contributed to the growth of such trading trends. Members of the communities often see high-risk day trading as an opportunity to quickly improve their financial conditions and obtain additional income. Some of the members tend to use borrowed capital, like student loans, to bet on certain "meme stocks" that show popularity within the community.[...] The "infinite leverage" glitch
Around November 2019, a user known as u/ControlTheNarrative found a bug in Robinhood's trading platform and exploited it to leverage his original deposit of $2,000 all the way up to roughly $50,000, resulting in a ratio of approximately 25:1 leverage. He sold covered calls and, thanks to the bug, the credit that he received appeared as liquid money on his account. He used the money to buy put options on Apple stock, a trade which led to a loss of $46,000, enormous relative to his initial deposit of only $2,000. He recorded the live reaction to his loss and uploaded it on his YouTube channel. Many other users tried to exploit the glitch, which they referred to as the "free money cheat code", before it was fixed, with one in particular claiming to have opened a $1,000,000 position from a $4,000 deposit."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R/wallstreetbets "Suicide of Alexander E. Kearns Robinhood faced controversy in June 2020 after University of Nebraska student Alexander E. Kearns committed suicide after seeing a negative cash balance of U.S. $730,000 in his Robinhood margin trading account. It was later discovered that this was a temporary negative balance due to unsettled trading activity. In his suicide note, Kearns, who was 20 years old at the time of his death, accused Robinhood of allowing him to pile on too much risk. In a press release, Robinhood promised considering additional criteria and education for customers seeking level 3 options authorization.[...] On January 28, 2021, Robinhood restricted the trading of certain stocks following an effort by users of r/wallstreetbets subreddit to drive up their price. This decision attracted condemnation from internet users on the subreddit and on Twitter. United States House Representative Rashida Tlaib called for a hearing by the House Committee on Financial Services, tweeting that Robinhood's action was "market manipulation" to protect hedge funds. Democratic representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted the restriction was “unacceptable,” saying Congress needed to know more about the company's decision “to block retail investors from purchasing stock while hedge funds are freely able to trade the stock as they see fit”, with Republican Ted Cruz and business magnate Elon Musk backing the sentiment."

9. Before 14 August 2021, will an executive order be signed or federal legislation become law that would forgive $10,000 or more in principal on federal student loan debts for at least five million student loan borrowers?
a. Initial Assessment: Ok, so there are a couple parts to this Q. First: Will Biden forgive student loans by executive order? A: Probably not. Biden thinks that his Constitutional authority on this is questionable, and he is unlikely to do it (https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamminsky/2021/01/15/3-reasons-why-biden-excluded-student-loan-relief-from-stimulus--and-what-it-means-for-borrowers/?sh=49f5e43964d0 ). Instead, he will likely extend the current pause on student loans in his first days in office, and rely on Congress for debt forgiveness (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-biden/biden-will-move-to-extend-pause-on-student-loan-payments-transition-official-idUSKBN29D2WM, https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/education/2021/01/08/student-loan-forgiveness-biden-freeze-interest-payment/6602401002/ ). Pressure is, however, mounting from Democrats for him to do this. Can Congress act fast enough to cancel the specified amount of debt by 14 August? A: Biden is planning to call on Congress to pass legislation providing $10,000 in student loan relief for every borrower. At first, however, the Senate would be busy approving Joe Biden’s nomination picks (https://www.rollcall.com/2020/12/22/senate-circulates-2021-calendar/ ).  Factors for:
•	Democratic control of House and Senate (+40%)
•	House and Senate Democrats both proposed a resolution that urged Joe Biden to cancel using executive action (+5%)
Factors against:
•	Congress will be busy confirming Biden nominations (-20%)
•	Republican filibuster (-40%) 50% + 45% - 70% = 25%

This means that it is likely to be included in the second round, which I would expect will be much more partisan and contentious. We sill see how hard the GOP fights to kill it there, but the fact that it won't be part of the first round of Corona re-organization is a small knock against its probability.

This article clarifies Biden's views on an "imperial presidency." I will start off low on probability. Even if Biden pressures Congress to do so, one half would have the fuel to push it forward but the other half may stop it. Passing laws in general let alone one specifically about student loans will be quite a stretch.
https://www.complex.com/life/2020/12/joe-biden-unlikely-to-cancel-50000-student-loan-debt-executive-order

In a Forbes article today, President-elect Biden said that he would be inclined (and legally able) to cancel about $10,000 in student loan debt, but would be unwilling to do as much as $50,000 as some Democratic legislators have been pushing for. https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamminsky/2020/12/23/biden-says-he-is-unlikely-to-cancel-50000-in-student-loan-debt-by-executive-order/?sh=2e21d07c15b6 To win this question, these criteria must be met:
1. The federal student loan debt forgiveness must be at least $10,000
2. The federal student loan debt forgiveness must cover at least five million student loan borrowers.
3. The aid must be signed into effect by 14 August 2021. Of these three criteria, the timeline seems like the biggest roadblock to winning this question. If Republicans win the Senate majority in the Georgia runoffs, then it seems unlikely that legislation could be passed in this time frame. Student loan forgiveness does not have the same kind of bipartisan support as the COVID stimulus, which took six months for a split Congress to push through. If there's divided government come Inauguration, don't expect legislation to get this done in the time frame stipulated by the question. The best shot would be an executive order, which Biden (in the linked article) seems open to doing. If Democrats manage to take the majority in the Senate, then fully expect at LEAST $10,000 in student loan forgiveness. As others have said, the 5mm number seems reasonable, given the number of Americans who hold federal student loan debt. The $10,000 figure might seem like too much money, but falls far short of the $50,000 that some progressives are pushing. To me, it seems likely that $10,000 would actually be a fair compromise if done by EO (again, pay attention to the GA runoffs and who takes majority). Ultimately, it seems likely that student loan debt forgiveness will be a key part of the economic recovery plan from COVID-19, and therefore a priority item for the Biden administration in the first 8 months in office.

So I think there is a decent chance that this will happen. However, I think part of that is that it may happen through legislation. The odds of this executive order occurring on the stated timeline depend heavily on how stimulus negotiations go once Biden comes into office. Precedent from 2008, when Obama came in, suggests that a measure like a stimulus bill which is both good for the economy and something that the GOP could blame the Dems for, will not face stiff congressional opposition and it would not surprise me if this measure makes its way into the stimulus bill. However that itself depends on who controls the Senate since there is a difference between McConnell not vigorously opposing something and actively working towards it. Even if it doesn't get done in the stimulus, if the stimulus meets enough democratic priorities I suspect Biden will not feel pressured to use unilateral executive action on a measure that most policy wonks consider to be a band-aid solution and bad for the institution of the presidency.  However, if there is mounted congressional opposition to debt forgiveness and the stimulus bill does not go far enough by economists and democratic leaders standards I believe there is a strong chance of this happening. A lot of Democratic heavyweights have lined up behind this idea (NAACP, teachers unions, Schumer, and Clayburn) and should the stimulus come short I doubt Biden will stay in the way of his party. TLDR: the probability of loan forgiveness is probably 55%, the specific probability of loan forgiveness through executive action is 40%. Pay close attention to how stimulus negotiations go and if the Dems take the senate. If the dems take the senate then the probability drops.
